batchMetadata.description: Advanced NFP accounting including contributions, endowments, split-interest agreements, and financial statement presentation

questions.question: A donor promises $500,000 to a charity if the charity raises $500,000 in matching funds within 12 months. The charity has historically always met matching requirements. How should this promise be recognized?

options.A: As unconditional contribution revenue immediately
options.B: As conditional contribution with no revenue until match is met
options.C: As a refundable advance until match is met
options.D: As revenue of $250,000 (50% probability)

questions.explanation: Under ASC 958-605, a conditional contribution has both a barrier (matching requirement) and a right of return/release if the condition is not met. The matching requirement is a barrier that must be overcome. Historical success in meeting conditions does not change the accounting - it remains conditional until the barrier is actually met. Revenue is recognized when the condition is substantially met.
questions.tip: Conditional contribution = Barrier + Right of return/release. Don't recognize until condition substantially met, regardless of probability.

questions.question: A museum received a $300,000 donation restricted for acquiring artwork. During the year, the museum purchased artwork costing $200,000 using these funds. What are the net asset reclassifications?

options.A: Release $200,000 from with donor restrictions to without donor restrictions
options.B: Release $300,000 from with donor restrictions to without donor restrictions
options.C: No reclassification; artwork remains in net assets with donor restrictions
options.D: Release $100,000 from with donor restrictions to without donor restrictions

questions.explanation: When purpose restrictions are satisfied (artwork purchased), the restriction is considered met and assets are reclassified. The $200,000 spent on artwork is released from net assets with donor restrictions to net assets without donor restrictions. The remaining $100,000 stays in net assets with donor restrictions until used for its restricted purpose.
questions.tip: Release from restriction when purpose is fulfilled. Only release the amount actually used for the restricted purpose.

questions.question: A university has a permanent endowment with an original gift of $2,000,000. Due to investment losses, the fair value is now $1,850,000. How should this be reported?

options.A: Net assets with donor restrictions of $2,000,000; loss reported separately
options.B: Net assets with donor restrictions of $1,850,000; $150,000 loss in without donor restrictions
options.C: Net assets with donor restrictions of $1,850,000
options.D: Net assets without donor restrictions of $1,850,000

questions.explanation: Under ASU 2016-14, underwater endowments (where fair value is below the original gift amount) are reported entirely in net assets with donor restrictions at fair value ($1,850,000). The $150,000 decline reduces net assets with donor restrictions. The original gift amount is disclosed in the notes. Prior standards (UPMIFA) may have different state law implications for spending from underwater endowments.
questions.tip: Underwater endowments: Report at fair value in net assets with donor restrictions. Disclose original gift and amounts underwater in notes.

questions.question: A CPA donates 100 hours of professional auditing services to a charity. The charity would have purchased these services if not donated. Under what conditions can the charity recognize contribution revenue?

options.A: Services can be recognized because they are professional
options.B: Services must create or enhance a nonfinancial asset OR require specialized skills and be from someone with those skills, and the charity would typically purchase them
options.C: All volunteer services must be recognized at fair value
options.D: Services cannot be recognized under any circumstances

questions.explanation: Contributed services are recognized only if they: (1) create or enhance nonfinancial assets, OR (2) require specialized skills, are provided by individuals possessing those skills, and would typically need to be purchased if not donated. CPA audit services meet the specialized skills criteria. Both contribution revenue and corresponding expense are recorded at fair value.
questions.tip: Contributed services: Specialized skills (legal, accounting, medical, etc.) + Would otherwise purchase. Record revenue and expense at fair value.

questions.question: A donor establishes a charitable lead trust, naming a hospital as the income beneficiary for 10 years. After 10 years, assets pass to the donor's heirs. How should the hospital account for this?

options.A: Record entire trust principal as contribution revenue
options.B: Record present value of expected income stream as contribution revenue
options.C: Record income only when received each year
options.D: No recording until the 10-year term ends

questions.explanation: In a charitable lead trust, the charity receives income for a period while others (remaindermen) receive principal later. The hospital should record contribution revenue equal to the present value of the expected income stream over the 10 years. Each year, the hospital recognizes changes in the value of the beneficial interest and actual income received.
questions.tip: Charitable lead trust: Charity gets income, others get remainder. Record PV of expected income stream. Charitable remainder trust is opposite.

questions.question: Under ASU 2016-14, NFPs must present expenses by both natural classification and functional classification. Which method is required for the primary financial statements?

options.A: Natural classification only, with functional in notes
options.B: Functional classification only, with natural in notes
options.C: Either method in the primary statement, with the other shown somewhere in financial statements
options.D: Both must appear in a matrix format on the face of the statements

questions.explanation: ASU 2016-14 requires NFPs to report expenses by both functional classification (program services, management and general, fundraising) and natural classification (salaries, rent, supplies). One method must be in the statement of activities or a separate statement; the other can be in the notes. A matrix format satisfies both requirements if presented.
questions.tip: NFP expenses: Functional + Natural required. One in statements, other in notes (or matrix showing both). Disclosure of allocation methods also required.

questions.question: A research university receives a $1,000,000 grant from a corporation. The corporation will receive exclusive licensing rights to any discoveries. How should this be classified?

options.A: Contribution revenue without donor restrictions
options.B: Contribution revenue with donor restrictions
options.C: Exchange transaction revenue
options.D: Deferred revenue until research is complete

questions.explanation: When the resource provider receives commensurate value (exclusive licensing rights) in exchange for resources provided, it's an exchange transaction, not a contribution. The corporation receives something of approximately equal value. Exchange transaction revenue is recognized as performance obligations are satisfied under ASC 606 principles, not contribution accounting.
questions.tip: Contribution vs exchange: Does provider receive commensurate value? Licensing rights = commensurate value = exchange transaction.

questions.question: A community foundation receives $100,000 from a donor who specifies the funds should benefit a specific charity. The foundation does NOT have variance power. How should the foundation report this?

options.A: Contribution revenue of $100,000
options.B: Liability to the specified beneficiary
options.C: Contribution revenue with donor restrictions
options.D: As a board-designated endowment

questions.explanation: When a recipient organization receives resources for a third-party beneficiary and lacks variance power (the ability to redirect assets to another beneficiary), it's an agency transaction. The foundation records an asset and liability, not contribution revenue. The ultimate beneficiary records contribution revenue. Variance power would allow the foundation to record contribution revenue.
questions.tip: No variance power + Specified beneficiary = Agency transaction (liability). With variance power = Contribution revenue.

questions.question: A museum receives a donated painting valued at $500,000. The museum's policy is to not capitalize collection items that meet specific criteria. What accounting is appropriate?

options.A: Must capitalize and record $500,000 contribution revenue
options.B: May choose not to capitalize if collection is held for public exhibition, protected, and unencumbered, with proceeds from sales used for other collection items
options.C: Must capitalize but need not record revenue
options.D: Cannot capitalize collection items under any circumstances

questions.explanation: NFPs have a policy choice for collection items if the collection: (1) is held for public exhibition, education, or research; (2) is protected, kept unencumbered, cared for, and preserved; and (3) proceeds from sales are used to acquire other collection items. If all criteria are met, the NFP can choose not to capitalize. If capitalized, fair value contribution revenue is recorded.
questions.tip: Collection items: Optional capitalization if 3 criteria met. Policy choice - but must be consistently applied. Disclose policy in notes.

questions.question: A donor pledges $100,000 per year for 3 years to a charity. The first payment is due immediately, with subsequent payments at the end of years 2 and 3. Discount rate is 5%. PV factors: Year 2 = 0.9524, Year 3 = 0.9070. What contribution revenue is recognized?

options.A: $300,000 without donor restrictions
options.B: $285,940 with donor restrictions
options.C: $100,000 without restrictions plus $185,940 with restrictions
options.D: $285,940 without donor restrictions

questions.explanation: Multi-year pledges are recorded at present value. First payment $100,000 (current) is without donor restrictions if no purpose restriction exists. Future payments: Year 2: $100,000 × 0.9524 = $95,240; Year 3: $100,000 × 0.9070 = $90,700. Total future = $185,940. Time restrictions exist for future payments (they can only be used in future periods), so recorded as with donor restrictions. Total revenue: $100,000 + $185,940 = $285,940.
questions.tip: Multi-year pledges: Record at PV. Future payments have time restrictions by default. As time passes, recognize discount amortization and release restrictions.

questions.question: A charity receives $200,000 in cash restricted by the donor for construction of a new building. How should this be classified in the statement of cash flows?

options.A: Operating activity
options.B: Investing activity
options.C: Financing activity
options.D: Either operating or financing, based on policy election

questions.explanation: Under ASC 958, contributions restricted for long-term purposes (such as building construction or endowment) are classified as financing activities in the NFP statement of cash flows. This differs from for-profit GAAP where most cash received would be operating. Operating activities include unrestricted contributions and contributions restricted for operating purposes.
questions.tip: NFP cash flows: Donor-restricted for long-term purposes = Financing. Restricted for operations = Operating. Differs from for-profit rules.

questions.question: A donor transfers $300,000 to a charity in exchange for a charitable gift annuity that will pay the donor $15,000 per year for life (estimated 12 years). The present value of the annuity obligation is $120,000. What contribution revenue should be recognized?
questions.explanation: A charitable gift annuity is a split-interest agreement. The charity receives assets and promises annuity payments. At inception: Record asset $300,000, liability for annuity obligation at present value $120,000, and contribution revenue for the difference $180,000 ($300,000 - $120,000). The contribution represents the charitable portion of the transaction.
questions.tip: Charitable gift annuity: Assets received - PV of annuity liability = Contribution revenue. Liability adjusts annually for payments and interest.

questions.question: A university's board of trustees designates $5,000,000 of unrestricted resources as a quasi-endowment for faculty research support. How is this classified?

options.A: Net assets with donor restrictions
options.B: Net assets without donor restrictions, disclosed as board-designated
options.C: A separate category of net assets
options.D: Removed from net assets and reported as a liability

questions.explanation: Board-designated (quasi) endowments are internally designated by the governing board, not externally restricted by donors. They remain in net assets without donor restrictions because the board can remove the designation at any time. ASU 2016-14 requires disclosure of amounts and purposes of board designations within net assets without donor restrictions.
questions.tip: Board designated ≠ donor restricted. Board can reverse its own designations. Report in without donor restrictions with disclosure.

questions.question: A not-for-profit hospital provides $2,000,000 in services to uninsured patients who qualify for charity care. How should this be reported?

options.A: Revenue of $2,000,000 with corresponding bad debt expense
options.B: No revenue or receivable recorded; disclosed in notes
options.C: Revenue of $2,000,000 with corresponding charity care expense
options.D: As a reduction of net assets with donor restrictions

questions.explanation: Charity care represents healthcare services provided without expectation of payment. Since collection is not expected, no revenue or receivable is recorded. The hospital discloses its charity care policy and the level of charity care provided (measured at cost or other metric) in the notes. This differs from bad debts, where payment was initially expected.
questions.tip: Charity care: No revenue or receivable. Disclosure only. Bad debt: Revenue initially recorded, then written off when uncollectible.

questions.question: Organization A receives a $50,000 contribution from a donor, immediately transferring it to Organization B per the donor's request. Organization A has no variance power but can substitute its own funds. How should Organization A account for this?

options.A: Record contribution revenue and grant expense of $50,000
options.B: No revenue or expense; agent liability only
options.C: Record contribution revenue with donor restrictions and corresponding expense
options.D: Record contribution revenue without donor restrictions

questions.explanation: When a recipient can substitute its own funds for the transferred assets (even without variance power), it's not a pure agency transaction. The ability to use own funds demonstrates discretion. Organization A records contribution revenue (with donor restrictions for the purpose) and expense when transferred. The substitution ability makes A more than a mere agent.
questions.tip: Pass-through: If can substitute own funds = revenue and expense. If pure conduit with no discretion = agency (no revenue).

questions.question: A university's endowment has accumulated earnings of $500,000 above the original gift. The university appropriates $100,000 under its spending policy. How is this reported?

options.A: Transfer from with donor restrictions to without donor restrictions
options.B: Reduction of net assets with donor restrictions only
options.C: As investment return in net assets without donor restrictions
options.D: As endowment distribution expense

questions.explanation: When an NFP appropriates endowment returns for expenditure under UPMIFA and its spending policy, it reclassifies the appropriated amount from net assets with donor restrictions (where accumulated investment returns reside) to net assets without donor restrictions (making them available for spending). This is shown as a release from restriction in the statement of activities.
questions.tip: Endowment spending appropriation: Reclassify from with donor restrictions to without. Shows as release from restriction on statement of activities.

questions.conceptTested: Perpetual trust held by third party
questions.question: A donor creates a perpetual trust at a bank with a charity as the sole income beneficiary. The bank holds and invests the assets. How should the charity report its interest?

options.A: Record the trust assets on its balance sheet
options.B: Record a beneficial interest asset equal to fair value of trust assets
options.C: Record only income when received
options.D: Disclose the arrangement in notes only

questions.explanation: When a charity is the beneficiary of a perpetual trust held by a third party, it recognizes a beneficial interest asset measured at fair value of the trust assets (its share if there are other beneficiaries). This is contribution revenue with perpetual donor restrictions. Changes in fair value are recognized in the statement of activities. The charity doesn't control the assets directly.
questions.tip: Beneficial interest in perpetual trust: Record asset at FV of trust assets. Contribution with perpetual restriction. Adjust annually for FV changes.

questions.question: Under ASU 2016-14, what must an NFP disclose regarding liquidity?

options.A: Only the current ratio
options.B: Qualitative information about managing liquidity and quantitative information about financial assets available within one year
options.C: Cash flow projections for the next five years
options.D: Only restrictions on assets

questions.explanation: ASU 2016-14 requires both qualitative and quantitative liquidity disclosures. Qualitative: How the NFP manages its liquidity and liquidity risk. Quantitative: Financial assets available within one year of the balance sheet date to meet cash needs, along with amounts not available due to donor restrictions, contractual limits, or board designations.
questions.tip: Liquidity disclosure: Qualitative (how managed) + Quantitative (assets available within 1 year, reduced by restrictions/designations).

questions.question: Two NFPs merge, with neither paying consideration. The merger is not between entities under common control. Under ASC 958-805, how are the acquired assets and liabilities measured?

options.A: At historical cost
options.B: At fair value, with any excess as goodwill
options.C: At book value of the larger entity
options.D: At fair value, with any excess as contribution or inherent contribution

questions.explanation: NFP mergers and acquisitions under ASC 958-805 use acquisition method accounting with assets and liabilities at fair value. Unlike for-profit combinations, excess of fair value acquired over consideration transferred is recognized as either a contribution received (if given voluntarily) or an inherent contribution (in involuntary combinations). Goodwill is not recognized for the excess.
questions.tip: NFP combinations: Fair value measurement. Excess = contribution/inherent contribution, not goodwill. Differs from ASC 805 for-profit treatment.

questions.question: An NFP receives a $600,000 government grant that is conditional on incurring qualifying program expenses. In Year 1, the NFP incurs $400,000 in qualifying expenses and receives $350,000 cash. What revenue is recognized in Year 1?
questions.explanation: Government grants with conditions (barriers that must be overcome) are recognized as revenue when the conditions are substantially met. The barrier here is incurring qualifying expenses. $400,000 in expenses triggers $400,000 in revenue. The $50,000 difference between revenue earned ($400,000) and cash received ($350,000) is a receivable. Remaining $200,000 is recognized when future qualifying expenses are incurred.
questions.tip: Conditional grants: Revenue when conditions met (expenses incurred), not when cash received. Track receivables/deferrals for timing differences.

questions.question: An NFP has pledges receivable of $500,000. Based on historical collection experience: pledges under 1 year have 5% uncollectible rate; pledges 1-5 years have 15% uncollectible rate. Current pledges: $300,000 due within 1 year, $200,000 due in 1-5 years. What is the allowance for uncollectible pledges?
questions.explanation: Allowance calculation: Current pledges ($300,000 × 5%) = $15,000. Longer-term pledges ($200,000 × 15%) = $30,000. Total allowance = $15,000 + $30,000 = $45,000. Multi-year pledges typically have higher uncollectible rates due to longer time horizons and changing donor circumstances.
questions.tip: Pledge allowances: Use historical collection rates by age. Longer-term pledges typically have higher uncollectible rates.

questions.question: An NFP charges annual membership dues of $150. Members receive a quarterly newsletter (fair value $20 each) and recognition on the website. How should the $150 be recognized?

options.A: All as contribution revenue
options.B: All as exchange revenue
options.C: $80 as exchange revenue (newsletters), $70 as contribution
options.D: Deferred and recognized ratably over the year

questions.explanation: Membership dues with identifiable exchange benefits are bifurcated. The fair value of benefits received ($20 × 4 newsletters = $80) is exchange revenue recognized as delivered. The excess ($150 - $80 = $70) is contribution revenue, recognized based on any donor-imposed restrictions. Website recognition is typically not measurable value.
questions.tip: Membership dues: Identify exchange component (fair value of benefits) vs contribution component. Website recognition usually has nominal value.

questions.question: An NFP has investments with no donor restrictions. During the year, it earned $50,000 in dividends, $30,000 in realized gains, and $40,000 in unrealized gains. How is the total investment return classified?

options.A: Dividends as operating, gains as non-operating
options.B: All $120,000 in net assets without donor restrictions
options.C: Dividends in without restrictions, unrealized gains in with restrictions
options.D: $80,000 without restrictions (realized), $40,000 with restrictions (unrealized)

questions.explanation: For investments without donor restrictions, all components of investment return (interest, dividends, realized gains/losses, unrealized gains/losses) are reported in net assets without donor restrictions. The total $120,000 ($50,000 + $30,000 + $40,000) is without donor restrictions. Presentation within the statement of activities may show investment return as a single line or component lines.
questions.tip: Investment return on unrestricted investments: All components in without restrictions. Restricted investments: Return follows the restriction.

questions.question: An NFP uses pooled investments. Beginning pool: 10,000 units at $100/unit = $1,000,000. Restricted endowment owns 6,000 units. During year: pool earns $80,000. What is the restricted endowment's share of earnings?
questions.explanation: In pooled investments, earnings are allocated based on units owned. Restricted endowment owns 6,000 / 10,000 = 60% of units. Share of earnings = $80,000 × 60% = $48,000. This amount would be credited to net assets with donor restrictions (endowment). The unit value method fairly allocates earnings across participants.
questions.tip: Pooled investments: Allocate returns based on unit ownership percentage. Each participant's share = Total return × (Their units / Total units).

questions.question: Under ASU 2020-07, what must an NFP disclose about contributed nonfinancial assets (gifts-in-kind)?

options.A: Only the total fair value received
options.B: Fair value by category, valuation techniques, and whether monetized or used in programs
options.C: Only donor names and restrictions
options.D: No disclosure required; just include in revenue

questions.explanation: ASU 2020-07 requires NFPs to present contributed nonfinancial assets as a separate line in the statement of activities and disclose: (1) disaggregated amounts by category, (2) qualitative information about whether items were monetized or utilized, (3) the NFP's policy for monetizing vs using, (4) valuation techniques, and (5) any donor restrictions.
questions.tip: ASU 2020-07: Separate line + Detailed disclosure. Categories, use vs monetization, valuation methods, restrictions.

questions.question: A donor contributes $200,000 with the instruction that principal be maintained for 20 years, after which it can be spent for any purpose. How is this classified?

options.A: Net assets with perpetual donor restrictions
options.B: Net assets with purpose restrictions
options.C: Net assets with time restrictions (term endowment)
options.D: Net assets without donor restrictions

questions.explanation: A term endowment requires the principal to be maintained for a specific period (20 years) rather than in perpetuity. This is a time restriction, so the gift is classified in net assets with donor restrictions. When the 20-year period expires, the restriction is released and the amount moves to net assets without donor restrictions.
questions.tip: Term endowment = Time-restricted. Perpetual endowment = Perpetual restriction. Both in 'with donor restrictions' but different duration.

questions.question: An NFP's executive director receives compensation that exceeds the reasonable amount by $100,000. What is the initial excise tax under intermediate sanctions rules?

options.A: 25% of the excess benefit
options.B: 100% of the excess benefit
options.C: 200% of the excess benefit
options.D: No tax; just requires repayment

questions.explanation: Under IRC §4958 intermediate sanctions, disqualified persons who receive excess benefit transactions face an initial excise tax of 25% of the excess benefit. If not corrected, an additional 200% tax applies. The organization's managers who knowingly approved the transaction may face $20,000 tax per transaction. This is disclosed in Form 990.
questions.tip: Intermediate sanctions: 25% initial tax on excess benefit. 200% additional if not corrected. Managers may face separate penalties.

questions.question: An NFP uses internal fund accounting with separate funds for operations, endowment, and building projects. How should external financial statements be presented?

options.A: Present each fund separately as a column
options.B: Present two net asset classes aggregating all funds
options.C: Present fund-level detail in primary statements
options.D: Use fund accounting format identical to governmental

questions.explanation: While NFPs may use fund accounting internally for tracking purposes, external financial statements present information by net asset classification (with or without donor restrictions), not by fund. All funds are aggregated into the two net asset classes. Fund-level detail may be shown in supplementary schedules but is not part of the required primary statements.
questions.tip: Internal fund accounting ≠ External reporting. External statements use net asset classification. Fund detail is internal/supplementary only.

questions.question: An NFP's board member owns a construction company that provides $500,000 of services to the NFP at fair value. What disclosure is required?

options.A: No disclosure required if at fair value
options.B: Disclose the nature and amount of the transaction
options.C: Only disclose if above market rates
options.D: Only disclose on Form 990, not financial statements

questions.explanation: Related party transactions require disclosure regardless of whether they are at fair value. ASC 850 requires disclosure of the nature of the relationship, description of the transaction, amounts involved, and any amounts due to/from related parties. Fair value pricing does not eliminate the disclosure requirement.
questions.tip: Related party transactions: Always disclose regardless of fair value. Nature, amounts, and relationship must be disclosed.

questions.question: A nonprofit receives rent-free use of office space from a donor. The fair rental value is $3,000 per month. The NFP also pays $500 monthly for utilities. What contribution revenue should be recognized annually?
questions.explanation: The contributed use of long-lived assets (including rent-free space) is recognized as contribution revenue at fair value. Annual contribution = $3,000 × 12 = $36,000. The utilities of $500/month ($6,000/year) paid by the NFP are a separate operating expense. The contribution is the fair value of what was donated (the rent), not net of expenses the NFP incurs.
questions.tip: Contributed facility use: Recognize at fair rental value. Don't reduce by operating costs paid by the NFP. Record revenue and corresponding rent expense.

questions.question: An NFP makes a $100,000 grant to another charity for hurricane relief. When should the granting organization recognize the expense?

options.A: When the grant application is approved
options.B: When the unconditional promise to give is made
options.C: When the cash is actually transferred
options.D: When the recipient completes the hurricane relief activities

questions.explanation: The granting organization recognizes expense when it makes an unconditional promise to transfer assets (a grant). This is the mirror of the recipient recognizing contribution revenue when an unconditional promise is received. If the grant is conditional, expense is recognized when conditions are met. Cash transfer timing is irrelevant for accrual accounting.
questions.tip: Grant expense: Recognized when unconditional promise made. Mirrors contribution revenue timing for recipient. Conditional grants = expense when conditions met.

questions.question: An NFP sends a mailing that includes educational content about disease prevention (program) and a donation request (fundraising). Under what conditions can costs be allocated between program and fundraising?

options.A: Whenever the mailing includes educational content
options.B: When purpose, audience, and content criteria are all met
options.C: Only when fundraising is less than 50% of the mailing
options.D: Never; all joint activities are 100% fundraising

questions.explanation: Under ASC 958-720, joint activity costs may be allocated between functional categories only if ALL three criteria are met: (1) Purpose - accomplishes program or management function, (2) Audience - selected based on ability to benefit from program or assist management, and (3) Content - supports program or management goals. If any criterion fails, all costs are fundraising.
questions.tip: Joint activity allocation: Purpose + Audience + Content tests ALL must pass. If any fails, 100% to fundraising.

questions.question: NFP A owns a majority of the voting stock of for-profit Company B. Under what circumstances must consolidation occur?

options.A: Never; NFPs cannot consolidate for-profit entities
options.B: Always when majority ownership exists
options.C: When there is both economic interest and control
options.D: Only if Company B is a healthcare entity

questions.explanation: Under ASC 958-810, NFPs consolidate entities when they have both an economic interest in and control of the other entity. For for-profit subsidiaries, majority ownership typically satisfies both criteria. The consolidated statements would show NFP activity combined with the for-profit, with appropriate elimination entries and, if applicable, noncontrolling interest.
questions.tip: NFP consolidation: Economic interest + Control. For-profit subsidiaries can be consolidated. Related entities without control = equity method or disclosure.

questions.question: An NFP is experiencing significant financial difficulty but management believes it can continue operating with planned cost reductions. What is required under GAAP?

options.A: Immediate switch to liquidation basis accounting
options.B: Evaluate whether substantial doubt exists about ability to continue as going concern and disclose if so
options.C: No disclosure required until bankruptcy is filed
options.D: Only auditors can make going concern assessments

questions.explanation: Under ASC 205-40 (applicable to NFPs), management must evaluate whether substantial doubt exists about the entity's ability to continue as a going concern within one year. If substantial doubt exists, disclosure is required. Management's plans to mitigate the conditions must be evaluated. The evaluation considers both conditions and management's plans.
questions.tip: Going concern: Management evaluates each period. Substantial doubt? Consider management's mitigation plans. Disclose conditions and plans if substantial doubt exists.

questions.question: An NFP holds a charity gala. Ticket price is $500, of which $200 represents the fair value of dinner and entertainment. The event generates $250,000 in ticket sales and $50,000 in sponsorships. Direct costs are $80,000. What is the contribution revenue?
questions.explanation: Special event revenue must be bifurcated between exchange (fair value of benefits) and contribution components. Ticket sales: $250,000 total, exchange portion is $200/$500 = 40% × $250,000 = $100,000 (revenue recognized as exchange). Contribution portion = $250,000 - $100,000 = $150,000. Sponsorships of $50,000 are typically contribution revenue. Total contribution = $150,000 + $50,000 = $200,000.
questions.tip: Special events: Bifurcate ticket price into exchange (FV of benefits) and contribution. Sponsorships are usually 100% contribution.
